item.title: Strategies for Success in 2015
item.description:
IÂ don't like resolutions. Remember 2013?

The problem with resolutions is that they simply set a goal. They don't provide a way to actually accomplish that goal, and often, they don't even determine if the goal is worth pursuing in the first place.

It's no wonder so many people set resolutions on January 1st only to see them fall apart in a month. Most resolutions are chosen on a whim, or are the result of compounding pain, not compelling vision.

It's not that resolutions themselves are bad, it's that they are missing the essentials of good growth:

  1. A clear mission/purpose
  2. Solid strategy
  3. Actionable goals

One of the key aspects of the Warrior Spirit is being dedicated to a cause or a mission. Having that foundation is what gives you the ability to muster superhuman determination in whatever you choose to do.

But...you can't know what goals matter unless you have a clear idea of your mission.

So, the first step in creating a strategy for 2015 is to refocus on your mission.

item.title: Can I do This?: A Question to Improve Performance on Everything
item.description:
Perhaps you've heard the old advice that it's important to psych yourself up before a big test or meeting. Remind yourself how awesome you are! Tell yourself, "I can do this! I'm a rockstar!" Maybe you've even done this, despite all feelings to the contrary.

If you've ever been in an airplane during extreme turbulence, you don't want to overhear your pilot insisting, "I can do this! Yeah!"

If they are talking at all, you want to hear specific actions that they will be taking to make things better.

There's a reason for this. Our minds actually interpret insistent statements like these as a sign that there is something really wrong. After all, if you were confident, you wouldn't even need to bother with the motivation at all, right?

Well, it turns out there's a better way to motivate yourself, one that feels less like a desperate plea to convince yourself of something you just don't believe, and that actually helps you do better, rather than simply feel better.

Ask the simple question, "Can I do this?"

item.title: Overcoming Weakness the Smart Way
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1528" align="alignright" width="300" caption="fPat on Flickr"][/caption]

Yesterday, I undertook the fourth installment of the CrossFit Sectionals Open Workouts. It looked right up my alley, involving two movements I am very good at - burpees and muscle ups - and only one that I wasn't - heavy overhead squat (really, I'm not good at much that is heavy).

Nevertheless, I was confident I would do well. All I had to do was suffer through the squats in order to get to one of my strengths. Unfortunately, I found the squats too much, and I didn't even manage to finish them before the timer buzzed.

I felt defeated. Even with the advantage of having my strengths, I was stopped by one thing that I'm weak at.
